title: 6 Easy Ways to Transfer Photos from iPhone to a PC or Mac

steps.title: Connect your iPhone to your Mac.
steps.content: Connect your iPhone to your Mac. [1] X Research source If prompted, tap Trust on the "Trust this computer?" on your iPhone before proceeding.

steps.title: Open the Photos app on your Mac .
steps.content: Open the Photos app on your Mac . You'll find this app on your Dock as well as on the Launchpad. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Select your iPhone under "Devices."
steps.content: Select your iPhone under "Devices." Once connected, you'll see the name of your iPhone in the left panel. Clicking it will open the Import screen in the right panel. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Choose where to import your photos.
steps.content: Choose where to import your photos. By default, "Library" is selected, which means you'll be importing photos to your photo library. You can choose a different location if you'd like.

steps.title: Select the photos you'd like to import.
steps.content: Select the photos you'd like to import. Just click each photo to select it. [4] X Research source Skip this step if you want to import all of the photos that aren't already on your computer.

steps.title: Click Import Selected or Import All New Items.
steps.content: Click Import Selected or Import All New Items . Choose the first option to import only the photos you've selected. To import all photos that aren't already on your Mac, choose Import All New Items instead. This imports the photos to your Mac. [5] X Research source Once imported, you can click the Imports folder in the left panel to see your photos. They'll also be visible in your Library if you didn't change that option.

steps.title: Connect your iPhone to your Windows computer.
steps.content: Connect your iPhone to your Windows computer. If this is the first time connecting your iPhone to the PC, tap Trust on the iPhone, then enter your iPhone's passcode or verify with Face or Touch ID. If you don't have iTunes on your computer, install it before proceeding.

steps.title: Open the Photos app on your PC.
steps.content: Open the Photos app on your PC. You'll find this app in your Windows Start menu under All Apps , or by searching for Photos .

steps.title: Click the Import icon.
steps.content: Click the Import icon. This icon is at the top-right corner of the Photos app. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Select your iPhone.
steps.content: Select your iPhone. If you're using Windows 11, you'll see your iPhone as one of the options in the menu. If you have Windows 10, select From a USB Device , and then choose your iPhone. If you get a prompt saying it can't find a USB item, close and re-open Photos and try again. It may take a couple of tries to get your iPhone to show up here.

steps.title: Select photos to transfer to your PC.
steps.content: Select photos to transfer to your PC. Check the box on each photo or video you want to import.

steps.title: Click Add items (Windows 11) or Import selected (Windows 10).
steps.content: Click Add items (Windows 11) or Import selected (Windows 10). On Windows 11, you'll see Add (number of) items at the top-right corner. On Windows 10, you'll see Import selected at the bottom. This final step imports all of the photos from your iPhone to your PC, where you can view them as often as you'd like in the Photos app.

steps.title: Open your iPhone's Settings.
steps.content: Open your iPhone's Settings. Tap the Settings app icon, which is a grey box with gears on it. [6] X Research source This method allows you to sync your photos to iCloud so they'll always be available in the Photos app on your Mac. You can also sync the photos on your Mac to iCloud so they'll be available on your iPhone. If you've already synced your photos to iCloud on your iPhone, skip to step 6 now.

steps.title: Tap your name.
steps.content: Tap your name. You'll see it at the top of the Settings app. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Tap iCloud.
steps.content: Tap iCloud . It's in the second section of the menu. [8] X Research source You'll see the amount of space on your iCloud account at the top of the screen. You'll start with 5 gigabytes of free storage, but you may need to upgrade your storage before you can store all of your photos.

steps.title: Tap Photos.
steps.content: Tap Photos . It's near the top of the "APPS USING ICLOUD" section.

steps.title: Toggle on the "Sync This Phone" switch .
steps.content: Toggle on the "Sync This Phone" switch . When this switch is on (green), all of the photos on your iPhone will automatically sync to your iCloud account whenever you're connected to Wi-Fi. [9] X Research source If it's your first time syncing your photos, the process may take a while.

steps.title: Open the Photos app on your Mac.
steps.content: Open the Photos app on your Mac. You'll find this app on the Launchpad. To see your iPhone photos on your Mac, you'll need to be signed in to your Mac using the same Apple ID you use on your iPhone.

steps.title: Click the Photos menu.
steps.content: Click the Photos menu. It's at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Click Settings (Ventura) or Preferences (macOS 12 and earlier).
steps.content: Click Settings (Ventura) or Preferences (macOS 12 and earlier). The name of this option will be different depending on your version of macOS. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Click iCloud.
steps.content: Click iCloud . Now you'll see all of your iCloud Photo preferences.

steps.title: Check the box next to "iCloud Photos."
steps.content: Check the box next to "iCloud Photos." This syncs the photos from iCloud to your Mac. It'll also sync any photos on your Mac to iCloud. If you want to automatically download the original photos from your iPhone to your Mac so they're available offline, select Download Originals to This Mac . If you'd rather only sync smaller versions of the photos to your Mac to conserve disk space, select Optimize Mac Storage instead.

steps.title: Open your iPhone's Settings.
steps.content: Open your iPhone's Settings. Tap the Settings app icon, which is a grey box with gears on it. This method allows you to sync your photos to iCloud so they'll always be available on your Windows PC. You can also sync the photos on your PC to iCloud so you can view them on your iPhone. If you've already synced your photos to iCloud on your iPhone, skip to step 6 now.

steps.title: Tap your name.
steps.content: Tap your name. You'll see it at the top of the Settings app.

steps.title: Tap iCloud.
steps.content: Tap iCloud . It's in the second section of the menu. You'll see the amount of space on your iCloud account at the top of the screen. You'll start with 5 gigabytes of free storage, but you may need to upgrade your storage before you can store all of your photos.

steps.title: Tap Photos.
steps.content: Tap Photos . It's near the top of the "APPS USING ICLOUD" section.

steps.title: Toggle on the "Sync This Phone" switch .
steps.content: Toggle on the "Sync This Phone" switch . When this switch is on (green), all of the photos on your iPhone will automatically sync to your iCloud account whenever you're connected to Wi-Fi. [11] X Research source If it's your first time syncing your photos, the process may take a while.

steps.title: Install iCloud for Windows on your PC.
steps.content: Install iCloud for Windows on your PC. This free app makes it easy to keep your iCloud Photo library synced across all of your devices. You can even sync the photos that are on your PC to iCloud so you can see them on your iPhone. [12] X Research source First, if you don't want to sync the photos from your PC to iCloud, you can simply access them using iCloud on the web. To do this, just go to https://www.icloud.com , sign in with your Apple ID, and click Photos . If you'd rather automatically download your iPhone photos to your PC and keep them synced across both devices, open the Microsoft Store app on your Windows 10 or 11 PC, search for iCloud , then click Install.

steps.title: Open the iCloud app on your PC.
steps.content: Open the iCloud app on your PC. Once installed, you'll find it in your Windows Start menu. The first time you open iCloud, you'll need to sign in with the same Apple ID you use on your iPhone.

steps.title: Check the box next to "iCloud Photos."
steps.content: Check the box next to "iCloud Photos." Turning on this feature will pop up the Photos Options menu. [13] X Research source If the Photos Options menu doesn't appear, click Options to open it now.

steps.title: Choose your preference and click Done.
steps.content: Choose your preference and click Done . To see your iPhone photos on your PC, you'll need to check the box next to "iCloud Photos." This option also syncs the photos from your PC to iCloud.

steps.title: Click Apply.
steps.content: Click Apply . Your photos will now sync to and from iCloud.

steps.title: Open the File Explorer on your PC.
steps.content: Open the File Explorer on your PC. You can do this by pressing Windows key + E on your keyboard or by right-clicking the Start menu and selecting File Explorer .

steps.title: Click iCloud Photos in the left panel.
steps.content: Click iCloud Photos in the left panel. If you don't see this option in the left panel, click Pictures , then double-click iCloud Photos . [14] X Research source You will now see all of the synced photos from your iPhone in this folder. If you just turned on photo syncing, you might need to wait a while before the photos are synced. Photos will only sync when your iPhone is connected to Wi-Fi. If you're using Windows 11 , you can also view your iPhone photos in your PC's Photos app, which you'll find in your Windows Start menu. Just click iCloud Photos in the Photos app to see your library.

steps.title: Make sure your iPhone and Mac are ready for AirDrop.
steps.content: Make sure your iPhone and Mac are ready for AirDrop. This method works best if you only have a few photos to share. Before you can AirDrop files from your iPhone to your Mac, make sure you're ready: The two devices are within Bluetooth and Wi-Fi range of one another so they'll be able to connect. [15] X Research source Wi-Fi and Bluetooth must be enabled on both devices. The iPhone must not be a Personal Hotspot .

steps.title: Open the Photos app on your iPhone.
steps.content: Open the Photos app on your iPhone. You'll find it on your Home screen or in your App Library.

steps.title: Tap Library.
steps.content: Tap Library . This displays all of your photos.

steps.title: Select the photos you want to send to your Mac.
steps.content: Select the photos you want to send to your Mac. To select multiple photos, tap Select at the top, then choose the photos you want to send. Otherwise, just tap one photo to open it.

steps.title: Tap the Share icon .
steps.content: Tap the Share icon . It's at the bottom-left corner. Several sharing options will appear.

steps.title: Tap AirDrop.
steps.content: Tap AirDrop . It's the white icon with several curved blue lines. Your iPhone will now scan for nearby AirDrop users and devices.

steps.title: Tap your Mac.
steps.content: Tap your Mac. You'll see your Mac under "Devices." Once selected, you'll see an AirDrop notification on your Mac.

steps.title: Click Accept on your Mac and save the files.
steps.content: Click Accept on your Mac and save the files. Once you click Accept , you'll be asked if you want to accept or save the files. [16] X Research source When prompted, choose to save the files to your Photos so you can easily access them in your Mac's Photos app.

steps.title: Open the Photos app on your iPhone.
steps.content: Open the Photos app on your iPhone. If you just want to send a few photos to your Mac, you can easily attach them to an email to yourself. Once you open the email on your PC or Mac, you can download the attached photos to the preferred location.

steps.title: Tap Library.
steps.content: Tap Library . This displays all of your photos.

steps.title: Select the photos you want to send to your PC or Mac.
steps.content: Select the photos you want to send to your PC or Mac. To select multiple photos, tap Select at the top, then choose the photos you want to send. Otherwise, just tap one photo to open it. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the Share icon .
steps.content: Tap the Share icon . It's at the bottom-left corner. Several sharing options will appear. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Select your email app.
steps.content: Select your email app. You can use any email app to send the photos, including the Mail app that came with your iPhone or the Gmail app . [19] X Research source Once selected, your iPhone will compose a new email message with the selected photos attached.

steps.title: Enter your own email address into the "To" field.
steps.content: Enter your own email address into the "To" field. Make sure to enter an address you can easily check on your PC or Mac.

steps.title: Tap the Send icon to send the email.
steps.content: Tap the Send icon to send the email. If you have too many photos selected, you may not be able to send the message due to size restrictions. Try selecting fewer photos if you have trouble sending.

steps.title: On your PC or Mac, sign in to your email account and open the email from yourself.
steps.content: On your PC or Mac, sign in to your email account and open the email from yourself. For example, if you sent the photos to your Gmail address, you'll sign in to Gmail in your web browser and click the email to open it.

steps.title: Download the attached photos to your Mac or PC.
steps.content: Download the attached photos to your Mac or PC. The step will be a little different depending on the email app you're using, but you'll usually be able to click a down-arrow on each photo and choose a saving location. Make sure to save the photo to your Pictures folder so they'll be instantly available in your Mac or PC's Photos app.
